title: Does Balanced Scoring Lead to Success in the Big East?
text:
The Big East is regarded as one of the the most competitive conferences in all of college basketball. Major powerhouses like UCONN and Villanova have won the NCAA tournament in 4 of the last 8 years. One question that often arises within the conference is whether the teams with balanced scoring, tend to perform better than teams relying on one or two star athletes. The correlation between scoring balance and success within the Big East is something we can determine, with a focus on how many players score in double figures and its impact on win percentage.

player_stats <- read.csv("C:/Users/jackb/Downloads/player_stats.csv")




Code
team_double_digit_count <- player_stats %>%
  filter(PTS >= 10) %>%  
  group_by(Team) %>%
  summarize(Players_in_double_digits = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(Players_in_double_digits))




Code
ggplot() +
  geom_bar(
    data = team_double_digit_count,
    aes(x = Team, y = Players_in_double_digits),
    stat = "identity",
    fill = "lightblue"
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "UCONN Dominates Once Again",
    subtitle = "Dan Hurley's squad is filled with stars",
    x = "School",
    y = "Players Averaging Double Digits",
    caption = "Source: sports-reference.com | By: Jack Beelman"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold", hjust = 0),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 10),
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1),
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = "black"),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "lightgray", color = "black"),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )











Code
team_performance <- left_join(team_double_digit_count, team_stats, by = "Team")




Code
sum(is.na(team_performance$Players_in_double_digits))


[1] 0


Code
sum(is.na(team_performance$win_percentage))


[1] 0




Code
team_performance_clean <- na.omit(team_performance)




Code
team_performance_clean <- team_performance %>%
  filter(Players_in_double_digits >= 0 & win_percentage >= 0 & win_percentage <= 1)




Code
team_stats <- team_stats %>%
  mutate(Team = ifelse(Team == "UConn", "Connecticut", Team))




Code
ggplot() +
  geom_line(
    data = team_performance_clean,
    aes(x = Players_in_double_digits, y = win_percentage, group = 1),
    color = "blue",
    size = 0.8
  ) +
  geom_point(
    data = team_performance_clean,
    aes(x = Players_in_double_digits, y = win_percentage),
    color = "blue",
    size = 4
  ) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data = team_performance_clean,
    aes(x = Players_in_double_digits, y = win_percentage, label = Team),
    box.padding = 0.5
  ) +
  geom_hline(
    yintercept = mean(team_performance_clean$win_percentage),
    color = "red",
    linetype = "dashed"
  ) +
  annotate(
    "text",
    x = 2,
    y = mean(team_performance_clean$win_percentage) + 0.02,
    label = "Avg Win%",
    color = "red",
    fontface = "italic"
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Does Scoring in Double Figures Lead to Success?",
    subtitle = "Teams with more players scoring double figures tend to win more",
    x = "Number of Players Scoring in Double Digits",
    y = "Win Percentage (%)",
    caption = "Source: sports-reference.com | By: Jack Beelman"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold", hjust = 0),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 14),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )
